awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Organic Cation Interactions with Soil Aluminosilicates:  Structure-Sorption Relationships
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Division of Chemistry at the National Science Foundation, addresses the need for more robust predictors of organic cation interactions with aluminosilicate minerals.  Professors Allison MacKay and José Gascon (University of Connecticut) and Dharni Vasudevan (Bowdoin College) in their collaboration will work closely with high school students and teachers to introduce cutting-edge chemistry concepts into public education. Their research activities provide two exciting and coupled avenues to facilitate increased K-12 chemistry literacy: Environmental issues, which are hot topics, and computer-based tools, which permeate our daily lives. The PIs will mentor post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate researchers through the processes of experimental design, manuscript preparation, and presentations at national professional societies. The PIs will continue their committed record of engaging student researchers from groups underrepresented in the sciences and engineering. The integrated team expertise in engineering (MacKay), chemistry (Vasudevan), molecular modeling (Gascon) and geochemistry (Collaborator Bourg) will enable research team members to develop broader perspectives of their individual research projects.

The collaborators will adapt computational biochemistry tools to the prediction of charged organic compound sorption, an important determinant of mobility, reactivity, and bioavailability of pesticides and pharmaceuticals following environmental release to soils.  The application of computational tools to environmental chemistry will advance our understanding of structure-sorption effects that are difficult to extract solely from experimental observations. This project examines application of the Linear Interaction Energy (LIE) approximation, a molecular dynamics approach with significant computational cost reductions, to identify contributions of van der Waals and electrostatic energies to overall sorption free energies for test sorbates on the representative soil aluminosilicate, montmorillonite. Results from this research will include mechanistic insights into sorption of environmental contaminants categorized as cationic amines to aluminosilicate minerals. This will advance the development of sorption models, allow the evaluation of LIE approximation methods for environmental chemistry applications, and provide integrated training for a research team of students from Primarily Undergraduate and Research 1 institutions.

por.por_cntn:
The environmental fate of emerging contaminants, such as pesticides and pharmaceuticals, is influenced by the sorption of these chemicals to solid phases such as sediments, soils, and clays. This study emphasizes the sorption of cationic amines, important substructures of many pesticides and pharmaceuticals, to soils and aluminosilicate clays. Recent advances in predictive models for aromatic cationic amine sorption have furthered our ability to anticipate the sorption of these contaminants. Efforts to date have focused on structures with amine moieties outside the aromatic ring (non-heterocyclic amines) but have not included heterocyclic amines, such as pyridines, in predictive model development.

This research is a collaborative effort between three institutions was aimed at quantitatively describing organic cation sorption to aluminosilicate surfaces and identifying structure-sorption relationships.  At Bowdoin College, PI Vasudevan and several undergraduate students focused on (i) developing a pulse input chromatography method to measure sorption equilibrium constants; (ii) measuring sorption of several heterocyclic amines as a function of aluminosilicate mineralogy, exchangeable inorganic cation identify and amine structure; (iii) identifying an appropriate probe compound that is effective at measuring site density and the baseline driving force for organic cation sorption to soils.

One of the goal of this study was to determine quantitative and qualitative differences in the nature and extent of heterocyclic and non-heterocyclic amine sorption to aluminosilicate clays. To accomplish this, pulse input chromatography was used to obtain isotherms for pyridine and 2, 3, and 4-methylpyridine sorption to montmorillonite and illite. Methyl substituents on the pyridine aromatic ring had a minor impact on the extent of sorption to montmorillonite and a greater influence on sorption to illite at low surface coverage, contrasting studies of methyl substituted non-heterocyclic amines, such as N-methylanilines. Favorable electrostatic overlap between pyridine?s delocalized positive charge and the defocused negative charges on clay receptor sites may reduce the importance of an increase in compound hydrophobicity following methyl substitution. Further, the greater influence of methyl substitution (and thus compound hydrophobicity) observed on illite may result from differences in the distribution of clay charges between octahedral and tetrahedral sites. Montmorillonite?s greater distribution of its charge in octahedral sheets (whose receptor sites possess more defocused charges) likely leads to more a favorable electrostatic attraction between pyridine and montmorillonite than illite, rendering compound hydrophobicity less important for pyridine sorption to montmorillonite.

Pyridines sorbed to a greater extent onto Na-montmorillonite than Ca-montmorillonite  and Na-illite than Ca-illite, although the influence of exchangeable cation identity was notably lower than that observed for non-heterocyclic amines. Pyridines more easily displaced exchangeable cations with a greater charge (e.g. Ca2+ vs. Na+) on montmorillonite, likely a result of a greater affinity of pyridines to montmorillonite?s octahedral receptor sites. Additionally, a greater affinity of pyridine to montmorillonite may reduce the influence of exchangeable cation identity on pyridine sorption relative to non-heterocyclic amines, which have a more localized amine positive charge.

With respect to identifying an appropriate probe compound that is effective at measuring site density and the baseline driving force for organic cation sorption, we explored sorption of two small amines (potential probes) , two  pharmaceuticals possessing nonheterocylic amine moieties and    one larger heterocyclic amine, within an aromatic ring onto 30 well characterized soils.  We  found that  PTMA was an effective probe compound for predicting the sorption  of larger more complex cationic amines.  This information incorporated into hybrid predictive model, published and co-authored by all PIs and several undergraduate students.    

This work has made important contributions to the training of next generation of scientists and engineers. Seven undergraduates have been trained in research: from posing a research question, to experimental design, data analysis, proposal and report writing, poster and oral presentations. All of the students have presented posters and oral presentations at Bowdoin College and four students have presented posters at national conferences.  Four students are coauthors on two publications, and four students are coauthors on a manuscript under preparation. 

In addition, to dissemination of research by student presentations and publications, PI Vasudevan has given oral presentations at National Meeting of American Chemical Society, University of New England, Rice University, University of Buffalo, Williams College, and University of Delaware.   Further, PI Vasudevan and two students presented this work to lay audience in the town of Brunswick.  Also PI Vasudevan and her students conducted several outreach efforts. We designed hands experiments demonstrating the charge on soils and potential for organic compounds to sorb to soils, using purple cool-aid, which was a lot of fun.  We interacted with students from local elementary schools, a group of high school students connected to a sustainable oceans project, and 8th grades from the Passamaquoddy reservation in Maine.
